lines.text: You may be right about money, Sharp; quite right. But there's one thing to be said for glory.
Yeah? What's that?
You can take glory with you when it's your time to go.
Walking through life with you, ma'am, has been a very gracious thing.
If the other outfits don't fight their way through, you're liable to have a lot of Sioux on your hands.
Yes. Yes, quite a lot of Sioux, Sharp. But the greater the odds, the greater the glory.
[the night before the battle, Custer asks Butler to take his last letter back to Fort Lincoln]
Why are you asking me to go back with it?
Well, for one thing you're an Englishman, not an American.
Not an American! What do you Yankees think you are? The only REAL Americans in this merry old parish are on the other side of the hill with feathers in their hatr.

You're probably right about that. But there's 6,000 of them... and less than 600 of us. The regiment's being sacrificed, Butler, and I wouldn't want to see a foreigner butchered in a dirty deal like this,

Sporty of you to think of it that way. But I'll remind you, sir, I'm a member of the mess of the Seventh U.S. Cavalry. Fancy walking into the Service Club in Picadilly if the regiment... Get somebody else to post your blinking letter!
Thanks, 'Queen's Own'. Just so long as you know.
[an owl wakes up Callie after Custer leaves]

[sees the owl]
What you have to wake up for, you old devil!
[the owl hoots very loud then winks at her]

[gasps]
Don't you wink at me!
Where is the regiment riding?
To hell, Sharp... or to glory. It depends on one's point of view.
[Custer addresses the officers after his arrival at Fort Lincoln]
since it's no more than hard work, hard riding and hard fighting. Thank you, gentlemen, I know I can count on you.

[raising his hand to start a peace conference]
Crazy Horse, war chief Sioux, speak with Long Hair, war chief Great White Father.

[raises his hand also]
I listen to my brother.
[after they first meet, Custer walks Miss Bacon to Gen. Sheridan's house]
Do you think if I were to come strolling past your house around nine o'clock at night you might be just sitting around on the veranda?
Life is full of surprises.
And if I did find you sitting on the porch perhaps you and I could go for a walk together.

[laughs]
We seem to have been walking together ever since we met.
Well, I can't imagine, ma'am - if I may say so - any pleasanter journey, ma'am, than walking through life with you beside me, ma'am.
This Custer of yours is insubordinate alright-thank God for it. He's not marching on Round Top. He's attacking Stuart at Hanover!
He's attacking! He's attacking a whole Corps! Rather than hold his ground the mad fool's attacking!
If he turns us, Washington and Baltimore will fall.
[Reads dispatch and recoils in horror]
Stuart! Stuart's Corps at Hanover? It's a mistake. Get verification at once!
It has been verified, sir.
He's on our rear. We're trapped. All that stands between us and total disaster is the Michigan brigade, a handful of volunteers.
But the Michigan Brigade's been ordered to Round Top! It's on it's way now!
Then stop it Taipe, stop it! Tell them to hold it's ground to the last man.
[Custer barely misses being dismissed from West Point for fighting]
You know, Taipe, I'm glad it turned out this way. There's something about that fellow I like.
Yeah? Well I don't know what it is. If you ask me, he'll make the worst record of any cadet at West Point since Ulysses S. Grant.

[on his cadet uniform]
I must get myself a tigerskin as soon as possible.
[California Joe is struck by an arrow at the battle of Little Bighorn and dying]
Ya dirty yella-bellied!... awhh, it looks like I'll never git ta...
[California Joe is driving the wagon in which Libby is riding on the trek to Fort Lincoln]

[to one of the horses]
Move over there, sweetheart, 'fore I cut the rest of your tail off!

[she looks at him, shocked]
I beg your pardon.
I said move over, you dirty Ethiopian son of a blue-bellied Mohawk!
You mean the horse.
